categories.category: Academics of the University of Nottingham

parameters.doctoral_students: Ben Moss, Razali Yaakob, Kristian Spoerer, Samih Tadrus, Yan Su, Limin Han, Naimah Hussin, Ruibin Bai, Masri Ayob, Glenn Whitwell, Steven Gustafson, Eric Soubeiga
parameters.field: Operations Research, Optimisation, Meta-heuristics, Hyper-heuristics, Scheduling, Evolutionary computation
parameters.name: Graham Kendall

row.col: This article or section is an , or has been extensively edited by the subject, and may not conform to Wikipedia's policy. Please see the relevant discussion on the .

bdy.p: Graham Kendall1, PhD, FORS (Fellow of the Operational Research Society2) (born July 21, 1961) is a Professor of Computer Science at The University of Nottingham, UK. He is a member of the Automated Scheduling, Optimisation and Planning (ASAP) Research Group 3 within the School of Computer Science http://www.nottingham.ac.uk/cs.

He is an Associate Editor of six international journals. He has been a member of the programme/technical committees of over 100 international conferences. He is the author of over 90 refereed papers and has co-edited (or is co-editing) 10 books. He chairs the Programme and Organising Committee of the international
MISTA
Conference Series]. He also co-chaired the inaugural IEEE Symposium on Computational Intelligence and Games in 2005 (held at The University of Essex, UK), and also chaired the second conference in Reno, Nevada, USA in 2006. In 2007, he co-chaired the first IEEE Symposium of Computational Intelligence and Scheduling (Hawaii, USA).
Professor Kendall has supervised ten PhD students to completion, and is currently supervising a further ten PhD students.

His research interests include
Scheduling (particularly sports scheduling)
cutting and packing. See, for example the bin packing problem, knapsack problem and packing problems
Optimisation
Operations Research
Meta-heuristics
Hyper-heuristics
Evolutionary computation
Artificial intelligence
game intelligence.
Before entering academia, Professor Kendall worked in the IT industry for fifteen years, holding a variety of technical and managerial positions.
